title: Severe Acute Pancreatitis
diagnosis_topic: Severe acute pancreatitis with systemic inflammatory response
setup_script: “A 45-year-old man with a history of heavy alcohol use presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. He has persistent vomiting and appears febrile. On examination, he is diaphoretic and appears acutely ill. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “Blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate 120 bpm, respiratory rate 24/min, temperature 38.5 °C.”
“Pain started suddenly yesterday, worsens after meals, radiates to the back. He denies gallstones but reports drinking six beers daily.”
“Serum lipase 1,200 U/L, amylase elevated, WBC 18,000/µL, BUN 25 mg/dL, calcium 7.5 mg/dL.”
“Ranson score 4 and BISAP score 3, consistent with severe pancreatitis.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests CT scan early
dynamic_flow.reply: “Initial CT scan shows peripancreatic inflammation but no necrosis. Repeat CT at 72 hours reveals necrosis of the pancreatic body.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates fluid resuscitation and pain control
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient receives lactated Ringer’s at 250 mL/hr and opioids. He is kept NPO. Blood pressure improves to 110/70 mmHg.”
“A nasojejunal feeding tube is placed within 48 hours. Patient tolerates feeds.”
“The patient becomes hypotensive, develops acute kidney injury, and requires ICU transfer.”
“The patient develops diarrhea and C. difficile infection. No evidence of infected pancreatic necrosis is found.”
“Over the next week, a pancreatic pseudocyst is identified on imaging.”
“Blood cultures are positive for gram-negative rods. CT-guided percutaneous drainage is performed. The patient remains febrile.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with surgical necrosectomy early (<4 weeks)
dynamic_flow.reply: “Operation is technically difficult due to lack of walling-off. Patient develops postoperative bleeding and worsening organ failure.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays necrosectomy until after 4 weeks
dynamic_flow.reply: “Operation proceeds with well-defined necrotic collection. Patient improves clinically. Please describe your operative steps in detail.”
“You perform an open transperitoneal approach to the necrotic cavity. Debridement is carried out until viable tissue is reached, drains are placed, and the abdomen is closed.”
“Referral to addiction services is made. Patient expresses willingness to stop drinking.”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of severe pancreatitis and application of severity scoring systems
Early aggressive fluid resuscitation and supportive management
Appropriate use and timing of imaging
Correct timing and method of intervention for infected necrosis
Ability to describe operative steps for pancreatic necrosectomy
Long-term management including nutrition and alcohol cessation
